trans-unit.source: How to use Azure queue storage with the WebJobs SDK
trans-unit.target: How to use Azure queue storage with the WebJobs SDK

trans-unit.source: Learn how to use Azure queue storage with the WebJobs SDK. Create and delete queues; insert, peek, get, and delete queue messages, and more.
trans-unit.target: Learn how to use Azure queue storage with the WebJobs SDK. Create and delete queues; insert, peek, get, and delete queue messages, and more.

trans-unit.source: This guide provides C# code samples that show how to use the Azure WebJobs SDK version 1.x with the Azure queue storage service.
trans-unit.target: This guide provides C# code samples that show how to use the Azure WebJobs SDK version 1.x with the Azure queue storage service.

trans-unit.source: The guide assumes you know <linkText>how to create a WebJob project in Visual Studio with connection strings that point to your storage account</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: The guide assumes you know <linkText>how to create a WebJob project in Visual Studio with connection strings that point to your storage account</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: Most of the code snippets only show functions, not the code that creates the JobHost object as in this example:
trans-unit.target: Most of the code snippets only show functions, not the code that creates the JobHost object as in this example:

trans-unit.source: To write a function that the WebJobs SDK calls when a queue message is received, use the QueueTrigger attribute.
trans-unit.target: To write a function that the WebJobs SDK calls when a queue message is received, use the QueueTrigger attribute.

trans-unit.source: The attribute constructor takes a string parameter that specifies the name of the queue to poll.
trans-unit.target: The attribute constructor takes a string parameter that specifies the name of the queue to poll.

trans-unit.source: You can also <linkText>set the queue name dynamically</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: You can also <linkText>set the queue name dynamically</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: In the following example, the queue contains a string message, so QueueTrigger is applied to a string parameter named logMessage which contains the content of the queue message.
trans-unit.target: In the following example, the queue contains a string message, so QueueTrigger is applied to a string parameter named logMessage which contains the content of the queue message.

trans-unit.source: The function <linkText>writes a log message to the Dashboard</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: The function <linkText>writes a log message to the Dashboard</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: Besides string, the parameter may be a byte array, a CloudQueueMessage object, or a POCO that you define.
trans-unit.target: Besides string, the parameter may be a byte array, a CloudQueueMessage object, or a POCO that you define.

trans-unit.source: In the following example, the queue message contains JSON for a BlobInformation object which includes a BlobName property.
trans-unit.target: In the following example, the queue message contains JSON for a BlobInformation object which includes a BlobName property.

trans-unit.source: The SDK automatically deserializes the object.
trans-unit.target: The SDK automatically deserializes the object.

trans-unit.source: The SDK uses the <linkText>Newtonsoft.Json NuGet package</linkText><title></title> to serialize and deserialize messages.
trans-unit.target: The SDK uses the <linkText>Newtonsoft.Json NuGet package</linkText><title></title> to serialize and deserialize messages.

trans-unit.source: If you create queue messages in a program that doesn't use the WebJobs SDK, you can write code like the following example to create a POCO queue message that the SDK can parse.
trans-unit.target: If you create queue messages in a program that doesn't use the WebJobs SDK, you can write code like the following example to create a POCO queue message that the SDK can parse.

trans-unit.source: The following async function <linkText>writes a log to the Dashboard</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: The following async function <linkText>writes a log to the Dashboard</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: Async functions may take a <linkText>cancellation token</linkText><title></title>, as shown in the following example which copies a blob.
trans-unit.target: Async functions may take a <linkText>cancellation token</linkText><title></title>, as shown in the following example which copies a blob.

trans-unit.source: (For an explanation of the queueTrigger placeholder, see the Blobs section.)
trans-unit.target: (For an explanation of the queueTrigger placeholder, see the Blobs section.)

trans-unit.source: You can use QueueTrigger with the following types:
trans-unit.target: You can use QueueTrigger with the following types:

trans-unit.source: string
trans-unit.target: string

trans-unit.source: A POCO type serialized as JSON
trans-unit.target: A POCO type serialized as JSON

trans-unit.source: byte[]
trans-unit.target: byte[]

trans-unit.source: CloudQueueMessage
trans-unit.target: CloudQueueMessage

trans-unit.source: The SDK implements a random exponential back-off algorithm to reduce the effect of idle-queue polling on storage transaction costs.
trans-unit.target: The SDK implements a random exponential back-off algorithm to reduce the effect of idle-queue polling on storage transaction costs.

trans-unit.source: When a message is found, the SDK waits two seconds and then checks for another message; when no message is found it waits about four seconds before trying again.
trans-unit.target: When a message is found, the SDK waits two seconds and then checks for another message; when no message is found it waits about four seconds before trying again.

trans-unit.source: After subsequent failed attempts to get a queue message, the wait time continues to increase until it reaches the maximum wait time, which defaults to one minute.
trans-unit.target: After subsequent failed attempts to get a queue message, the wait time continues to increase until it reaches the maximum wait time, which defaults to one minute.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>The maximum wait time is configurable</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: <linkText>The maximum wait time is configurable</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: If your web app runs on multiple instances, a continuous WebJobs runs on each machine, and each machine will wait for triggers and attempt to run functions.
trans-unit.target: If your web app runs on multiple instances, a continuous WebJobs runs on each machine, and each machine will wait for triggers and attempt to run functions.

trans-unit.source: In some scenarios this can lead to some functions processing the same data twice, so functions should be idempotent (written so that calling them repeatedly with the same input data doesn't produce duplicate results).
trans-unit.target: In some scenarios this can lead to some functions processing the same data twice, so functions should be idempotent (written so that calling them repeatedly with the same input data doesn't produce duplicate results).

trans-unit.source: If you have multiple functions listening on different queues, the SDK will call them in parallel when messages are received simultaneously.
trans-unit.target: If you have multiple functions listening on different queues, the SDK will call them in parallel when messages are received simultaneously.

trans-unit.source: The same is true when multiple messages are received for a single queue.
trans-unit.target: The same is true when multiple messages are received for a single queue.

trans-unit.source: By default, the SDK gets a batch of 16 queue messages at a time and executes the function that processes them in parallel.
trans-unit.target: By default, the SDK gets a batch of 16 queue messages at a time and executes the function that processes them in parallel.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>The batch size is configurable</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: <linkText>The batch size is configurable</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: When the number being processed gets down to half of the batch size, the SDK gets another batch and starts processing those messages.
trans-unit.target: When the number being processed gets down to half of the batch size, the SDK gets another batch and starts processing those messages.

trans-unit.source: Therefore the maximum number of concurrent messages being processed per function is one and a half times the batch size.
trans-unit.target: Therefore the maximum number of concurrent messages being processed per function is one and a half times the batch size.

trans-unit.source: This limit applies separately to each function that has a QueueTrigger attribute.
trans-unit.target: This limit applies separately to each function that has a QueueTrigger attribute.

trans-unit.source: If you don't want parallel execution for messages received on one queue, set the batch size to 1.
trans-unit.target: If you don't want parallel execution for messages received on one queue, set the batch size to 1.

trans-unit.source: You can get the following message properties by adding parameters to the method signature:
trans-unit.target: You can get the following message properties by adding parameters to the method signature:

trans-unit.source: DateTimeOffset expirationTime
trans-unit.target: DateTimeOffset expirationTime

trans-unit.source: DateTimeOffset insertionTime
trans-unit.target: DateTimeOffset insertionTime

trans-unit.source: DateTimeOffset nextVisibleTime
trans-unit.target: DateTimeOffset nextVisibleTime

trans-unit.source: string queueTrigger (contains message text)
trans-unit.target: string queueTrigger (contains message text)

trans-unit.source: string id
trans-unit.target: string id

trans-unit.source: string popReceipt
trans-unit.target: string popReceipt

trans-unit.source: int dequeueCount
trans-unit.target: int dequeueCount

trans-unit.source: If you want to work directly with the Azure storage API, you can also add a CloudStorageAccount parameter.
trans-unit.target: If you want to work directly with the Azure storage API, you can also add a CloudStorageAccount parameter.

trans-unit.source: The following example writes all of this metadata to an INFO application log.
trans-unit.target: The following example writes all of this metadata to an INFO application log.

trans-unit.source: In the example, both logMessage and queueTrigger contain the content of the queue message.
trans-unit.target: In the example, both logMessage and queueTrigger contain the content of the queue message.

trans-unit.source: Here is a sample log written by the sample code:
trans-unit.target: Here is a sample log written by the sample code:

trans-unit.source: A function that runs in a continuous WebJob can accept a CancellationToken parameter which enables the operating system to notify the function when the WebJob is about to be terminated.
trans-unit.target: A function that runs in a continuous WebJob can accept a CancellationToken parameter which enables the operating system to notify the function when the WebJob is about to be terminated.

trans-unit.source: You can use this notification to make sure the function doesn't terminate unexpectedly in a way that leaves data in an inconsistent state.
trans-unit.target: You can use this notification to make sure the function doesn't terminate unexpectedly in a way that leaves data in an inconsistent state.

trans-unit.source: The following example shows how to check for impending WebJob termination in a function.
trans-unit.target: The following example shows how to check for impending WebJob termination in a function.

trans-unit.source: Note: The Dashboard might not correctly show the status and output of functions that have been shut down.
trans-unit.target: Note: The Dashboard might not correctly show the status and output of functions that have been shut down.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see <linkText>WebJobs Graceful Shutdown</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For more information, see <linkText>WebJobs Graceful Shutdown</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: To write a function that creates a new queue message, use the Queue attribute.
trans-unit.target: To write a function that creates a new queue message, use the Queue attribute.

trans-unit.source: Like QueueTrigger, you pass in the queue name as a string or you can set the queue name dynamically.
trans-unit.target: Like QueueTrigger, you pass in the queue name as a string or you can set the queue name dynamically.

trans-unit.source: The following non-async code sample creates a new queue message in the queue named "outputqueue" with the same content as the queue message received in the queue named "inputqueue". (For async functions use IAsyncCollector as shown later in this section.)
trans-unit.target: The following non-async code sample creates a new queue message in the queue named "outputqueue" with the same content as the queue message received in the queue named "inputqueue". (For async functions use IAsyncCollector as shown later in this section.)

trans-unit.source: To create a queue message that contains a POCO rather than a string, pass the POCO type as an output parameter to the Queue attribute constructor.
trans-unit.target: To create a queue message that contains a POCO rather than a string, pass the POCO type as an output parameter to the Queue attribute constructor.

trans-unit.source: The SDK automatically serializes the object to JSON.
trans-unit.target: The SDK automatically serializes the object to JSON.

trans-unit.source: A queue message is always created, even if the object is null.
trans-unit.target: A queue message is always created, even if the object is null.

trans-unit.source: To create multiple messages, make the parameter type for the output queue ICollector or IAsyncCollector, as shown in the following example.
trans-unit.target: To create multiple messages, make the parameter type for the output queue ICollector or IAsyncCollector, as shown in the following example.

trans-unit.source: Each queue message is created immediately when the Add method is called.
trans-unit.target: Each queue message is created immediately when the Add method is called.

trans-unit.source: You can use the Queue attribute on the following parameter types:
trans-unit.target: You can use the Queue attribute on the following parameter types:

trans-unit.source: out string (creates queue message if parameter value is non-null when the function ends)
trans-unit.target: out string (creates queue message if parameter value is non-null when the function ends)

trans-unit.source: out byte[] (works like string)
trans-unit.target: out byte[] (works like string)

trans-unit.source: out CloudQueueMessage (works like string)
trans-unit.target: out CloudQueueMessage (works like string)

trans-unit.source: out POCO (a serializable type, creates a message with a null object if the paramter is null when the function ends)
trans-unit.target: out POCO (a serializable type, creates a message with a null object if the paramter is null when the function ends)

trans-unit.source: ICollector
trans-unit.target: ICollector

trans-unit.source: IAsyncCollector
trans-unit.target: IAsyncCollector

trans-unit.source: CloudQueue (for creating messages manually using the Azure Storage API directly)
trans-unit.target: CloudQueue (for creating messages manually using the Azure Storage API directly)

trans-unit.source: If you need to do some work in your function before using a WebJobs SDK attribute such as Queue, Blob, or Table, you can use the IBinder interface.
trans-unit.target: If you need to do some work in your function before using a WebJobs SDK attribute such as Queue, Blob, or Table, you can use the IBinder interface.

trans-unit.source: The following example takes an input queue message and creates a new message with the same content in an output queue.
trans-unit.target: The following example takes an input queue message and creates a new message with the same content in an output queue.

trans-unit.source: The output queue name is set by code in the body of the function.
trans-unit.target: The output queue name is set by code in the body of the function.

trans-unit.source: The IBinder interface can also be used with the Table and Blob attributes.
trans-unit.target: The IBinder interface can also be used with the Table and Blob attributes.

trans-unit.source: The Blob and Table attributes enable you to read and write blobs and tables.
trans-unit.target: The Blob and Table attributes enable you to read and write blobs and tables.

trans-unit.source: The samples in this section apply to blobs.
trans-unit.target: The samples in this section apply to blobs.

trans-unit.source: For code samples that show how to trigger processes when blobs are created or updated, see <linkText>How to use Azure blob storage with the WebJobs SDK</linkText><title></title>, and for code samples that read and write tables, see <linkText>How to use Azure table storage with the WebJobs SDK</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For code samples that show how to trigger processes when blobs are created or updated, see <linkText>How to use Azure blob storage with the WebJobs SDK</linkText><title></title>, and for code samples that read and write tables, see <linkText>How to use Azure table storage with the WebJobs SDK</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: For a queue message that contains a string, queueTrigger is a placeholder you can use in the Blob attribute's blobPath parameter that contains the contents of the message.
trans-unit.target: For a queue message that contains a string, queueTrigger is a placeholder you can use in the Blob attribute's blobPath parameter that contains the contents of the message.

trans-unit.source: The following example uses Stream objects to read and write blobs.
trans-unit.target: The following example uses Stream objects to read and write blobs.

trans-unit.source: The queue message is the name of a blob located in the textblobs container.
trans-unit.target: The queue message is the name of a blob located in the textblobs container.

trans-unit.source: A copy of the blob with "-new" appended to the name is created in the same container.
trans-unit.target: A copy of the blob with "-new" appended to the name is created in the same container.

trans-unit.source: The Blob attribute constructor takes a blobPath parameter that specifies the container and blob name.
trans-unit.target: The Blob attribute constructor takes a blobPath parameter that specifies the container and blob name.

trans-unit.source: For more information about this placeholder, see <linkText>How to use Azure blob storage with the WebJobs SDK</linkText><title></title>,
trans-unit.target: For more information about this placeholder, see <linkText>How to use Azure blob storage with the WebJobs SDK</linkText><title></title>,

trans-unit.source: When the attribute decorates a Stream object, another constructor parameter specifies the FileAccess mode as read, write, or read/write.
trans-unit.target: When the attribute decorates a Stream object, another constructor parameter specifies the FileAccess mode as read, write, or read/write.

trans-unit.source: The following example uses a CloudBlockBlob object to delete a blob.
trans-unit.target: The following example uses a CloudBlockBlob object to delete a blob.

trans-unit.source: The queue message is the name of the blob.
trans-unit.target: The queue message is the name of the blob.

trans-unit.source: For a POCO stored as JSON in the queue message, you can use placeholders that name properties of the object in the Queue attribute's blobPath parameter.
trans-unit.target: For a POCO stored as JSON in the queue message, you can use placeholders that name properties of the object in the Queue attribute's blobPath parameter.

trans-unit.source: You can also use <linkText>queue metadata property names</linkText><title></title> as placeholders.
trans-unit.target: You can also use <linkText>queue metadata property names</linkText><title></title> as placeholders.

trans-unit.source: The following example copies a blob to a new blob with a different extension.
trans-unit.target: The following example copies a blob to a new blob with a different extension.

trans-unit.source: The queue message is a BlobInformation object that includes BlobName and BlobNameWithoutExtension properties.
trans-unit.target: The queue message is a BlobInformation object that includes BlobName and BlobNameWithoutExtension properties.

trans-unit.source: The property names are used as placeholders in the blob path for the Blob attributes.
trans-unit.target: The property names are used as placeholders in the blob path for the Blob attributes.

trans-unit.source: The SDK uses the <linkText>Newtonsoft.Json NuGet package</linkText><title></title> to serialize and deserialize messages.
trans-unit.target: The SDK uses the <linkText>Newtonsoft.Json NuGet package</linkText><title></title> to serialize and deserialize messages.

trans-unit.source: If you create queue messages in a program that doesn't use the WebJobs SDK, you can write code like the following example to create a POCO queue message that the SDK can parse.
trans-unit.target: If you create queue messages in a program that doesn't use the WebJobs SDK, you can write code like the following example to create a POCO queue message that the SDK can parse.

trans-unit.source: If you need to do some work in your function before binding a blob to an object, you can use the attribute in the body of the function, <linkText>as shown earlier for the Queue attribute</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: If you need to do some work in your function before binding a blob to an object, you can use the attribute in the body of the function, <linkText>as shown earlier for the Queue attribute</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: The Blob attribute can be used with the following types:
trans-unit.target: The Blob attribute can be used with the following types:

trans-unit.source: Stream (read or write, specified by using the FileAccess constructor parameter)
trans-unit.target: Stream (read or write, specified by using the FileAccess constructor parameter)

trans-unit.source: TextReader
trans-unit.target: TextReader

trans-unit.source: TextWriter
trans-unit.target: TextWriter

trans-unit.source: string (read)
trans-unit.target: string (read)

trans-unit.source: out string (write; creates a blob only if the string parameter is non-null when the function returns)
trans-unit.target: out string (write; creates a blob only if the string parameter is non-null when the function returns)

trans-unit.source: POCO (read)
trans-unit.target: POCO (read)

trans-unit.source: out POCO (write; always creates a blob, creates as null object if POCO parameter is null when the function returns)
trans-unit.target: out POCO (write; always creates a blob, creates as null object if POCO parameter is null when the function returns)

trans-unit.source: CloudBlobStream (write)
trans-unit.target: CloudBlobStream (write)

trans-unit.source: ICloudBlob (read or write)
trans-unit.target: ICloudBlob (read or write)

trans-unit.source: CloudBlockBlob (read or write)
trans-unit.target: CloudBlockBlob (read or write)

trans-unit.source: CloudPageBlob (read or write)
trans-unit.target: CloudPageBlob (read or write)

trans-unit.source: Messages whose content causes a function to fail are called poison messages.
trans-unit.target: Messages whose content causes a function to fail are called poison messages.

trans-unit.source: When the function fails, the queue message is not deleted and eventually is picked up again, causing the cycle to be repeated.
trans-unit.target: When the function fails, the queue message is not deleted and eventually is picked up again, causing the cycle to be repeated.

trans-unit.source: The SDK can automatically interrupt the cycle after a limited number of iterations, or you can do it manually.
trans-unit.target: The SDK can automatically interrupt the cycle after a limited number of iterations, or you can do it manually.

trans-unit.source: The SDK will call a function up to 5 times to process a queue message.
trans-unit.target: The SDK will call a function up to 5 times to process a queue message.

trans-unit.source: If the fifth try fails, the message is moved to a poison queue.
trans-unit.target: If the fifth try fails, the message is moved to a poison queue.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>The maximum number of retries is configurable</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: <linkText>The maximum number of retries is configurable</linkText><title></title>.

trans-unit.source: The poison queue is named {originalqueuename}-poison.
trans-unit.target: The poison queue is named {originalqueuename}-poison.

trans-unit.source: You can write a function to process messages from the poison queue by logging them or sending a notification that manual attention is needed.
trans-unit.target: You can write a function to process messages from the poison queue by logging them or sending a notification that manual attention is needed.

trans-unit.source: In the following example the CopyBlob function will fail when a queue message contains the name of a blob that doesn't exist.
trans-unit.target: In the following example the CopyBlob function will fail when a queue message contains the name of a blob that doesn't exist.

trans-unit.source: When that happens, the message is moved from the copyblobqueue queue to the copyblobqueue-poison queue.
trans-unit.target: When that happens, the message is moved from the copyblobqueue queue to the copyblobqueue-poison queue.

trans-unit.source: The ProcessPoisonMessage then logs the poison message.
trans-unit.target: The ProcessPoisonMessage then logs the poison message.

trans-unit.source: The following illustration shows console output from these functions when a poison message is processed.
trans-unit.target: The following illustration shows console output from these functions when a poison message is processed.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Console output for poison message handling</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Console output for poison message handling</linkText>

trans-unit.source: You can get the number of times a message has been picked up for processing by adding an int parameter named dequeueCount to your function.
trans-unit.target: You can get the number of times a message has been picked up for processing by adding an int parameter named dequeueCount to your function.

trans-unit.source: You can then check the dequeue count in function code and perform your own poison message handling when the number exceeds a threshold, as shown in the following example.
trans-unit.target: You can then check the dequeue count in function code and perform your own poison message handling when the number exceeds a threshold, as shown in the following example.

trans-unit.source: You can use the JobHostConfiguration type to set the following configuration options:
trans-unit.target: You can use the JobHostConfiguration type to set the following configuration options:

trans-unit.source: Set the SDK connection strings in code.
trans-unit.target: Set the SDK connection strings in code.

trans-unit.source: Configure QueueTrigger settings such as maximum dequeue count.
trans-unit.target: Configure QueueTrigger settings such as maximum dequeue count.

trans-unit.source: Get queue names from configuration.
trans-unit.target: Get queue names from configuration.

trans-unit.source: Setting the SDK connection strings in code enables you to use your own connection string names in configuration files or environment variables, as shown in the following example.
trans-unit.target: Setting the SDK connection strings in code enables you to use your own connection string names in configuration files or environment variables, as shown in the following example.

trans-unit.source: You can configure the following settings that apply to the queue message processing:
trans-unit.target: You can configure the following settings that apply to the queue message processing:

trans-unit.source: The maximum number of queue messages that are picked up simultaneously to be executed in parallel (default is 16).
trans-unit.target: The maximum number of queue messages that are picked up simultaneously to be executed in parallel (default is 16).

trans-unit.source: The maximum number of retries before a queue message is sent to a poison queue (default is 5).
trans-unit.target: The maximum number of retries before a queue message is sent to a poison queue (default is 5).

trans-unit.source: The maximum wait time before polling again when a queue is empty (default is 1 minute).
trans-unit.target: The maximum wait time before polling again when a queue is empty (default is 1 minute).

trans-unit.source: The following example shows how to configure these settings:
trans-unit.target: The following example shows how to configure these settings:

trans-unit.source: Sometimes you want to specify a queue name, a blob name or container, or a table name in code rather than hard-code it.
trans-unit.target: Sometimes you want to specify a queue name, a blob name or container, or a table name in code rather than hard-code it.

trans-unit.source: For example, you might want to specify the queue name for QueueTrigger in a configuration file or environment variable.
trans-unit.target: For example, you might want to specify the queue name for QueueTrigger in a configuration file or environment variable.

trans-unit.source: You can do that by passing in a NameResolver object to the JobHostConfiguration type.
trans-unit.target: You can do that by passing in a NameResolver object to the JobHostConfiguration type.

trans-unit.source: You include special placeholders surrounded by percent (%) signs in WebJobs SDK attribute constructor parameters, and your NameResolver code specifies the actual values to be used in place of those placeholders.
trans-unit.target: You include special placeholders surrounded by percent (%) signs in WebJobs SDK attribute constructor parameters, and your NameResolver code specifies the actual values to be used in place of those placeholders.

trans-unit.source: For example, suppose you want to use a queue named logqueuetest in the test environment and one named logqueueprod in production.
trans-unit.target: For example, suppose you want to use a queue named logqueuetest in the test environment and one named logqueueprod in production.

trans-unit.source: Instead of a hard-coded queue name, you want to specify the name of an entry in the appSettings collection that would have the actual queue name.
trans-unit.target: Instead of a hard-coded queue name, you want to specify the name of an entry in the appSettings collection that would have the actual queue name.

trans-unit.source: If the appSettings key is logqueue, your function could look like the following example.
trans-unit.target: If the appSettings key is logqueue, your function could look like the following example.

trans-unit.source: Your NameResolver class could then get the queue name from appSettings as shown in the following example:
trans-unit.target: Your NameResolver class could then get the queue name from appSettings as shown in the following example:

trans-unit.source: You pass the NameResolver class in to the JobHost object as shown in the following example.
trans-unit.target: You pass the NameResolver class in to the JobHost object as shown in the following example.

trans-unit.source: Note: Queue, table, and blob names are resolved each time a function is called, but blob container names are resolved only when the application starts.
trans-unit.target: Note: Queue, table, and blob names are resolved each time a function is called, but blob container names are resolved only when the application starts.

trans-unit.source: You can't change blob container name while the job is running.
trans-unit.target: You can't change blob container name while the job is running.

trans-unit.source: To trigger a function manually, use the Call or CallAsync method on the JobHost object and the NoAutomaticTrigger attribute on the function, as shown in the following example.
trans-unit.target: To trigger a function manually, use the Call or CallAsync method on the JobHost object and the NoAutomaticTrigger attribute on the function, as shown in the following example.

trans-unit.source: The Dashboard shows logs in two places: the page for the WebJob, and the page for a particular WebJob invocation.
trans-unit.target: The Dashboard shows logs in two places: the page for the WebJob, and the page for a particular WebJob invocation.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Logs in WebJob page</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Logs in WebJob page</linkText>

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Logs in function invocation page</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Logs in function invocation page</linkText>

trans-unit.source: Output from Console methods that you call in a function or in the Main() method appears in the Dashboard page for the WebJob, not in the page for a particular method invocation.
trans-unit.target: Output from Console methods that you call in a function or in the Main() method appears in the Dashboard page for the WebJob, not in the page for a particular method invocation.

trans-unit.source: Output from the TextWriter object that you get from a parameter in your method signature appears in the Dashboard page for a method invocation.
trans-unit.target: Output from the TextWriter object that you get from a parameter in your method signature appears in the Dashboard page for a method invocation.

trans-unit.source: Console output can't be linked to a particular method invocation because the Console is single-threaded, while many job functions may be running at the same time.
trans-unit.target: Console output can't be linked to a particular method invocation because the Console is single-threaded, while many job functions may be running at the same time.

trans-unit.source: That's why the SDK provides each function invocation with its own unique log writer object.
trans-unit.target: That's why the SDK provides each function invocation with its own unique log writer object.

trans-unit.source: To write application tracing logs, use Console.Out (creates logs marked as INFO) and Console.Error (creates logs marked as ERROR).
trans-unit.target: To write application tracing logs, use Console.Out (creates logs marked as INFO) and Console.Error (creates logs marked as ERROR).

trans-unit.source: An alternative is to use <linkText>Trace or TraceSource</linkText><title></title>, which provides Verbose, Warning, and Critical levels in addition to Info and Error.
trans-unit.target: An alternative is to use <linkText>Trace or TraceSource</linkText><title></title>, which provides Verbose, Warning, and Critical levels in addition to Info and Error.

trans-unit.source: Application tracing logs appear in the web app log files, Azure tables, or Azure blobs depending on how you configure your Azure web app.
trans-unit.target: Application tracing logs appear in the web app log files, Azure tables, or Azure blobs depending on how you configure your Azure web app.

trans-unit.source: As is true of all Console output, the most recent 100 application logs also appear in the Dashboard page for the WebJob, not the page for a function invocation.
trans-unit.target: As is true of all Console output, the most recent 100 application logs also appear in the Dashboard page for the WebJob, not the page for a function invocation.

trans-unit.source: Console output appears in the Dashboard only if the program is running in an Azure WebJob, not if the program is running locally or in some other environment.
trans-unit.target: Console output appears in the Dashboard only if the program is running in an Azure WebJob, not if the program is running locally or in some other environment.

trans-unit.source: Disable dashboard logging for high throughput scenarios.
trans-unit.target: Disable dashboard logging for high throughput scenarios.

trans-unit.source: By default, the SDK writes logs to storage, and this activity could degrade performance when you are processing many messages.
trans-unit.target: By default, the SDK writes logs to storage, and this activity could degrade performance when you are processing many messages.

trans-unit.source: To disable logging, set the dashboard connection string to null as shown in the following example.
trans-unit.target: To disable logging, set the dashboard connection string to null as shown in the following example.

trans-unit.source: The following example shows several ways to write logs:
trans-unit.target: The following example shows several ways to write logs:

trans-unit.source: In the WebJobs SDK Dashboard, the output from the TextWriter object shows up when you go to the page for a particular function invocation and click Toggle Output:
trans-unit.target: In the WebJobs SDK Dashboard, the output from the TextWriter object shows up when you go to the page for a particular function invocation and click Toggle Output:

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Click function invocation link</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Click function invocation link</linkText>

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Logs in function invocation page</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Logs in function invocation page</linkText>

trans-unit.source: In the WebJobs SDK Dashboard, the most recent 100 lines of Console output show up when you go to the page for the WebJob (not for the function invocation) and click Toggle Output.
trans-unit.target: In the WebJobs SDK Dashboard, the most recent 100 lines of Console output show up when you go to the page for the WebJob (not for the function invocation) and click Toggle Output.

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Click Toggle Output</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Click Toggle Output</linkText>

trans-unit.source: In a continuous WebJob, application logs show up in /data/jobs/continuous/{webjobname}/job_log.txt in the web app file system.
trans-unit.target: In a continuous WebJob, application logs show up in /data/jobs/continuous/{webjobname}/job_log.txt in the web app file system.

trans-unit.source: In an Azure blob the application logs look like this: 2014-09-26T21:01:13,Information,contosoadsnew,491e54,635473620738373502,0,17404,17,Console.Write - Hello world!, 2014-09-26T21:01:13,Error,contosoadsnew,491e54,635473620738373502,0,17404,19,Console.Error - Hello world!, 2014-09-26T21:01:13,Information,contosoadsnew,491e54,635473620738529920,0,17404,17,Console.Out - Hello world!,
trans-unit.target: In an Azure blob the application logs look like this: 2014-09-26T21:01:13,Information,contosoadsnew,491e54,635473620738373502,0,17404,17,Console.Write - Hello world!, 2014-09-26T21:01:13,Error,contosoadsnew,491e54,635473620738373502,0,17404,19,Console.Error - Hello world!, 2014-09-26T21:01:13,Information,contosoadsnew,491e54,635473620738529920,0,17404,17,Console.Out - Hello world!,

trans-unit.source: And in an Azure table the Console.Out and Console.Error logs look like this:
trans-unit.target: And in an Azure table the Console.Out and Console.Error logs look like this:

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Info log in table</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Info log in table</linkText>

trans-unit.source: <linkText>Error log in table</linkText>
trans-unit.target: <linkText>Error log in table</linkText>

trans-unit.source: This guide has provided code samples that show how to handle common scenarios for working with Azure queues.
trans-unit.target: This guide has provided code samples that show how to handle common scenarios for working with Azure queues.

trans-unit.source: For more information about how to use Azure WebJobs and the WebJobs SDK, see <linkText>Azure WebJobs Recommended Resources</linkText><title></title>.
trans-unit.target: For more information about how to use Azure WebJobs and the WebJobs SDK, see <linkText>Azure WebJobs Recommended Resources</linkText><title></title>.
